msDesc.head: Letter from Mary Russell Mitford to T.N. Talfourd, 1821 October 22.

support.p: Folio sheet of paper folded in half to form four quarto pages, with correspondence on 1-3 and address leaf on page 4, then folded in thirds twice more and sealed for posting.

Address leaf bearing the following postmarks: 1) black postmark, illegible, and 2) a sepia indented single rim oval stamp reading
10 o'Clock
25 OC
1822
A large 2 denoting the fee for a single-sheet letter has been written in black ink by the postal service across the address leaf.

condition.p: The right edge of page three is torn.

sealDesc.p: Red wax seal, wrong side showing.

handNotes.handNote: Someone cataloging the letters, apparently other than Mitford, numbered each on page 1. This letter numbered 15.

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice," “sic," and “reg" to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

div.p:
I am always sinning--not quite tragical sins; & repenting--not quite perhaps with a tragical repentenace, but very sincerely & uncomfortably of the thousand faults which inconsideration & want of tact make me commit every day & almost every hour--to say nothing of my terrible tendency to say from pure flutter what I should not & what I do not mean, & not to say from sheer awkwardness what I should say & do mean. Ever since I So that whoever comes into my company had need provide themselves with a large stock of charity & forgiveness. But this is worse than my usual misdoings. Ever since I gave you my wretched article on Friday morning, I have had the consciousness that nobody but you ought to have attempted it--especially that I should not--that being, upon occasion, as obstinate as my neighbors, I should have given the dear Doctor a touch of my quality, instead of taking the post assigned me so quietly & really checking my father when with a much better taste & feeling he tried to get me off. I only thought at the moment how shabby it would be to turn over a disagreeable occupation to you, quite forgetting that the subject & the school & the charm of writing of Reading & for Reading would have made it almost as pleasant as it would have been to you delightful to every body everybodyelse--How could I be so foolish & presumptuous!
When I found by your condescending note how much trouble you had taken--& that you still had another account to write & not for Reading--I was more ashamed & more angry with myself (& this is saying much) than ever I was in my life. Well the dear Doctor is fitly punished in the abominable badness of my report, & so am I. I have a good mind to apologize to the poor boys in the next paper for cheating them of your valuable praise. You must write a Magazine Article to console them. In the mean time meantime I could not resist the opportunity of asking your pardon afforded by our sending Miss James a basket of roots & flower seeds & such underground treasures the announcement of which you had the goodness to convey. She will of course think my note contains more last words of Foscari. Do not notice it even to say you forgive me--I am so ashamed.

Did I beg you to tell Mr. Macready that I should willingly & thankfully make any & every alteration that he might suggest in Foscari, in case, which I do not expect, he should deem it worth altering. I have just finished my new copy & am more & more conscious that the part is utterly unworthy of his great powers. He might to be sure be everything to the play as he was to FoscariWallace--my usual consolation when I think of the badness of Foscari--but that is too much to ask. Perhaps there is more opportunity for an Actor in the Doge--at least he might make that part which could hardly be done in Foscari. But this
must of course be left to him & you. I thank you very much for the report of Mr. Quale--& rely on his zeal & kindness. But I have very little hope. Since this last weary copying, I am come back to my original opinion of the general feebleness of the Play--Just as I had done Papa told me ofthe "sweets & dears"--Shall I write it over again to get quit of them? Or shall we wait to hear whatMr. Macready says? As soon as I was to send this I found it out--just as in the case of the "own Really my stupidity is hopeless. How you can you have such patience with me--Such indulgence such great kindness I cannot imagine. I don't think I shall attempt the "Euripedean Enterprise"--Oh it is quite quite above me--I shall leave that to your Tragedy--& beguile my hopes & fears for Foscari. (Did not I say just now that I had no hope?) by the soothing & sedative properties of needlework the most composing & quieting occupation in the world. Luckily I have a dozen jobs that cry out to be done. It is almost--not quite--worthwhile to be a woman to have such a resource.

Did I--was I bold enough to ask you when we were talking of your article on Homer & I was wishing so much to see it--did I ask you to lend it to me? And will you? And that on the Greek Tragedians if it comes your way? Will you? I want to read a translation of Mr. Burgess recommended one in French prose--but French prose--will not English be better? And pray when you saw that astonishing thing about my writing a Comedy--(in which we seemed mutually to amuse each other) did you mean it quite, really? Or was it only
a very pretty way of saying "I don't think, Madam, that "you will ever make much of Tragedy"--?

My father is going to the Doctor's dance tonight--he sent me a very kind invitation on Saturday--but I stay away from pure cowardice--I really cannot encounter Mrs. Culpepper. I wonder if they won't prevail on you to stay.--My fingers are so cramped with writing that they slide every way but the right--Good bye. God bless you--pray forgive me.

postscript.p: Pray excuse all my blots & blunders--I had better not have written. but I could not help it--
